metadata.name: Euphonic #913
metadata.description:
Euphonic is an exploration of the emergent visual properties that arise from placing layers of simple lines atop one another.

In general this effect is called the Moir√© effect. This effect really feels best in the tactile - when you have a printed page and an acetate sheet. This piece attempts to recreate that tactile joy.

This is built in WebGL 2 and so doesn't work in Safari 14 and below. All latest browsers will work as expected.

Licensing: BY-NC-ND see license.md for details.

metadata.name: Tympanic #26
metadata.description:
Tympanic is a companion piece to Euphonic [https://www.fxhash.xyz/generative/10982] and is released as a free gift to all collectors of Euphonic.

Like Euphonic, this piece attempts to play with the idea of interference and emergent patterns, but this time does so by using pixelation instead of Moire. In this way, where Euphonic was about emergent melodies, Tympanic is about emergent rhythms.

This is built in WebGL 2 and so doesn't work in Safari 14 and below. All latest browsers will work as expected.

Licensing: BY-NC-ND see license.md for details.

metadata.name: Ichigo #267
metadata.description:
This generator is named 'Ichigo' (Ëã∫/ „ÅÑ„Å°„Åî), the Japanese word for 'strawberry'. 

Seeing each iteration from a suitable distance, small dots (to me, reminiscent of strawberry seeds) overlay different sequences of geometric repetitions, implying a sense of texture, grittiness and irregularity. 

By looking closer however, it becomes apparent to the viewer that the majority of the composition is in fact government by orderly elements, in this case grids of dots. 

This discovery invites the viewer to consider the output in front of them at different levels, near and far. At what point do you feel the dots begin to dissolve into a texture? When do you stop noticing the dots and instead begin to perceive the overall composition?

These questions are posed in a similar fashion as with meditation; at what point does something become something else? When does an in-breath become an out-breath and vice versa? 

Contemplation on simple questions like these can open a small portal into stillness and mindfulness by taking time to slowly observe our responses. 

23 palettes are included, each named after different areas of Tokyo. 

Press 'S' to download a full size 6000px x 6000px PNG output. 

As always, much gratitude and enjoy your piece.

metadata.name: √âtudes(Reissued) #129
metadata.description:
√âtudes(Reissued) is a patched and upgraded version of √âtudes(Project #10993).

√âtudes was originally published on April 16, 2022. Because of technical issues (audio doesn‚Äôt play due to external link usage) we prepared this reissue to its current holders.

You can visit the original project with this link - https://www.fxhash.xyz/generative/10993 


This reissue comprises of some fixes and additional new features as mentioned below;

New Features;

- New ‚Äòcolored‚Äô mode; now has colored noteheads and stems. Added new sampler for the colored mode: Marimba.
- Added a new synth for ‚Äòinverted & colored‚Äô mode; DuoSynth.

Fixes;

- Fixed canvas size to prevent additional notes being added in live mode. Now it‚Äôs consistent.
- Samples are now in the zip rather than in an external link, and won't break in the future.
- More consistent (but still sometimes buggy) sonification and audio playback.
- Fixed some minor issues and re-adjusted some probabilities.


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

- Click to start the sound -

‚Äò√âtudes‚Äô is a series of generative notation accompanied with sound.

‚Äò√âtudes‚Äô is the first series of the ‚ÄòNotations‚Äô collection. ‚ÄòNotations‚Äô will explore various notation techniques around the world and will use different sonification techniques and generative music algorithms.

In this series, a sonification process has been used to generate sound.

Some articulations or accidentals intentionally exist due to aesthetic preferences. For example there are some musically meaningless things like vibrato on a piano or a coda sign on a motif. And some notes will play the same pitch (even if they appear apart from one another) depending on the chosen scale.

Sonification tends to work better after 2nd (or even 3rd) play. Some minor audio bugs might occur.

There is a major but a rare bug which we intentionally kept in; it plays a generative piece from indicated pitches rather than just playing the motif only once.

There is a rare possibility that ‚Äò√âtudes‚Äô can generate an ‚Äòelectronic‚Äô result which plays with a FM synth instead of piano. 

Probabilities;

- 12 root notes

- 12 different scales

- Dynamics; pp,p,mp,mf,f,ff or none

- Dynamic changes; crescendo and diminuendo or none

- 4 different noteheads

- Several accidentals and articulations

- Vibrato might occur on some outputs

- 3 font styles

- 4 background textures


Made with p5.js
Ilgƒ±n ƒ∞√ß√∂z√º, March 2022(Reissued-September 2022)
@distcollective

metadata.name: terra[incognita] #186
metadata.description:
This piece is an exploration of grids, shapes and colors.

There are 3 different layouts: square, landscape & portrait.
There are 5 different grid sizes.
There are 15 different color palettes.
Some pieces have more layers, others less, but all of them looking equally good in their own right.

Press ‚Äòs‚Äô to save a PNG
Press ‚Äòh‚Äô to save an SVG (for lossless scaling)

15% royalties
1st buyer of each mint will get 25% of those royalties

- Jerome Herr (2022) 

@jeromeherrcc on Twitter

metadata.name: Mythologic #916
metadata.description:
"Mythologic" is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at The Ever-Evolving World of Art, Art Basel Hong-Kong, 2022.

Mythologic is a project derived from cloud series, Cloud Atlas and Requiem: Cloud on fxhash. In the series, lines and circles are used in an organics movement like Cloud Hands, which is a move of Tai Chi. Practitioners move their hands slowly and smoothly, make circles and rotate with extreme concentrating. In Chinese we said ‚Äúfloating clouds and flowing water‚Äù to describe calligraphers‚Äô freely flowing style of writing. Chi is a very important for oriental artists, and for genart as well. In the series, lines and circles start from one position to another, and develop with organic rotations and movements, like practicing Tai Chi on the canvas. 

Mythologic was inspired from ‚ÄúClassic of Mountains and Seas‚Äù, also known as Shan Hai Jing, is a Chinese classic text and a compilation of mythic geography and beasts. 

‚ÄúThere is a beast that looks like a fox with nine tails.‚Äù 
‚ÄúHuangbei: it is a beetle with meat like a tadpole, but with a head and a tail‚Äù 
‚ÄúThe beast has the body of a fish but the wings of a bird‚Äù 

There are many incredible creatures in the text which describe the oriental fantasy. The idea of Mythologic is to present an illustrated handbook with random generated paintings, each one is like a framed badge, to memorize the glorious age. It uses the "cloud hands" technique in every parts of this piece, the center, the circle and the frame. They are all the same algorithm but perform variety with different density and components. Gold, Silver, Copper, Jade and Ruby colors as noble symbol of treasure in Chinese culture. 

This project use p5js. 

Press 'S' to save pictures.

Thanks to the support of Yi-Wen Lin in this project.

metadata.name: GM.GEN.MATH #25
metadata.description:
Released on the occasion of the Tribute to Herbert W. Franke.
100% of the proceeds from primary sales are donated to the Foundation Herbert W. Franke. 
https://www.tribute-hwf.com/

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Undisputably, my mathematical background makes me naturally attracted to graphs, math functions, and transformations. I use math in ways that mathematicians could consider nonsense, but which produce fascinating aesthetic elements for creation (to paraphrase Herbert W. Franke). Combining scientific symbols and illustrations with fictional data produces pseudo-persuasive generative imagery that we can easily take to be absolute truth or in which we find meaningful patterns.
In the special issue of Leonardo, Visual Mathematics from 1992, Herbert W. Franke and Horst S. Helbig published the article Generative Mathematics: Mathematically Described and Calculated Visual Art.

They propose that ‚ÄúThrough the use of [mathematical] formulas (software) we gain generative principles. Beyond formal descriptions, we obtain guides for the construction of images. For example, if we use a parametric representation of a curve, the result is similar to traditional methods of drawing and painting [‚Ä¶]‚Äú Additionally, mathematics removes frame limits and adds the possibilities for transitions, transformations, movement, and interaction by implementing simple changes to the defining parameters.

I‚Äôm also very fond of the analysis and comparison (mentioned there) of digitally generated images and Constructivist design. Limitations of the technology (in the 70s) allowed only simple line drawings, based on fixed proportions same as Constructivists did. ‚ÄúIn a short time, all possible features were exhausted, so it became an obvious goal to try to extend them. This was done first by the use of random generators ‚Äî a highly interesting expansion of design principles [‚Ä¶]‚Äù Another expansion happened by adding curved shapes, first simple then complex that overcame possibilities of drawing with compasses and rulers. ‚Äú[‚Ä¶] oscillating curves are easily obtained through mathematical formulas and computer-graphic systems. The results we achieve on this basis do not look like Constructivist presentations, but their rationality and precision derive from Constructivist principles. ‚Äù

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Each mint contains both dark and light version, use D/N keys to switch between ‚Äúday & night‚Äù.
 
Base shapes are circles or Lissajous curves modified by the noise function. Shapes are arranged in a grid or by a circle packing algorithm. Lines are drawn smoothly or in stripes. Around 20% of the mints have lines in only one color (black/white). 

Depending on the browser/configuration rendering times will vary.

metadata.name: Little Trees #209
metadata.description:
Delicate, little trees. Some with green leaves, some with orange, some with red. This is the genesis project of Brian Gawlik.

The default resolution is 3600x3600. To redraw and save as an image at a different resolution - in the live view, open your browser's devtools and execute the function saveImg(pixWidth) where pixWidth is the desired width in pixels of the image. For example, saveImg(4096) will prompt you to download a 4096x4096 image. It is recommended not to export below 2400x2400 as this will compromise the aesthetic of the shadow.

metadata.name: Untitled #98
metadata.description: An untitled abstract generative piece.  Made with pure p5js and a WebGL shader.

metadata.name: Elswhere #155
metadata.description:
Perlin noise walks into a Julia set and finds itself Elswhere. X is real, Y is imaginary, or is it the other way around? 

Elswhere is a unique generative art series in which noise and fractal math are combined to create whimsical shapes and motifs, with an infinite number of variations. Made with p5js.

For each pixel, the noise values corresponding to the X and Y coordinates are computed and then used as the real and imaginary components for initializing a Julia set recursion. The pixel is colored based on the number of steps it takes for the recursion to reach its base case.

Keyboard controls:
[S] Save the current view.
[2] Render 2000x3000px image.
[4] Render 4000x6000px image.
[6] Render 6000x9000px image.

Created by Elsif, 2022.05

metadata.name: Orbs #187
metadata.description:
Serene orbs,
Playfully dynamic,
Soft visceral airy bodies,
Bold, colorful, at once moving, still, tiny, colossal,
Intimate organized chaos, both calm and ethereally energetic

(Created with p5.js and a WEBGL shader.)

metadata.name: el inefable momento #1005
metadata.description:
"el inefable momento del colorido descubrimiento" ("the ineffable moment of the colorful discovery")  is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at The Ever-Evolving World of Art, Art Basel Hong-Kong, 2022.

It is a tribute to playful discovery. This work was commissioned for the Art Basel Hong Kong / Tezos / fxhash collaboration, as part of an activity to introduce visitors into generative art. As I was pondering what could I do in the short time available, I saw my youngest daughter drawing: the ineffable moment of colorful discovery. Child play is one of the most discovery-filled activities I can think of. And drawing is that joy that I describe: a blank piece of paper with a crayon is pure possibility. Which is what generative art is. I had wanted for quite some time to create a tribute to those drawings my daughters do, and this has been the perfect occasion to start it: it seemed to me that it fit the occasion perfectly: kids discover through painting, maybe adults can discover generative art using the same visual language.

"el inefable momento del colorido descubrimiento" is a work that explores colour and irregular basic shapes, and that leaves the viewer in front of a new space with each execution. Does it trigger any excitement to see those imperfect elements? It is dearest to me to see the hearts and rainbows, as two mainstays of the drawings that I keep in folders and count in the hundreds and thousands. Can an algorithm that reproduces those elements trigger the same warm feelings in the viewer? It does with me.

The piece lets the viewer explore certain characteristics. The viewer can pause the iterations: each is just an execution of the same drawing, slightly different. When paused, one can look at each line individually and notice how the drawing is constructed. When running, it gives an idea of how the things we know are just versions of the ideal concept they represent. 

Also, one can have an idea of what would have happened if the child had decided to draw more or less elements. The viewer can press ‚Äúe‚Äù to see different variations of the same piece: random elements are selected and displayed. To restore the original work, press ‚Äúr‚Äù. Which one is the ‚Äúfinished‚Äù artwork? All of them. What is ‚Äúthe‚Äù artwork? 

The work has the following commands:

- Change the work: ‚Äúe‚Äù. To restore: ‚Äúr‚Äù
- The painting can be paused/unpaused pressing ‚Äúp‚Äù
- The viewer can save an artwork pressing ‚Äús‚Äù (it will pause the piece, press "p" to unpause)
- The resolution can be arbitrarily changed pressing ‚Äúd‚Äù followed by a number from 1 to 9. If the image goes dark and nothing paints, press ‚Äúd 0‚Äù (d zero) and try again with a lower number. Resolution can be increased iteratively: press d 2, then d 2, etc. It will always add the amount to the current pixel density, thus increasing resolution.
- The viewer can see how many decisions are made per iteration. This might be interesting to those who don‚Äôt know how generative art works. Each iteration is composed of thousands of decisions that inform colour, positions, shapes, etc. To toggle the decision count view, press ‚Äúq‚Äù
- It has also colour controls: press z for brightness, x for contrast, g for gamma, b for blur, n for noise followed by + or - to alter their values. You might get some simple variations that you might enjoy. Press a to enable/disable all colour controls (except the noise).
- There are some pre-recorded colour variations: press ‚Äúv‚Äù followed by 1, 2 or 3. Press ‚Äúv‚Äù followed by 0 (zero) to reset the variations.

In every process of discovery, one comes to an "aha" moment ;) If you find your aha moment, then you can do one more thing: you can play with the size of certain elements pressing ‚Äúo‚Äù. To restore, reload the piece. Once you find your aha moment, you can go back the same way you got there. All the controls work the same when one has reached their aha moment.

I hope you enjoy the piece as much as I have enjoyed drawing it, directly or indirectly, with my daughters. Thanks.

Artwork by Marcelo Soria-Rodr√≠guez, @msoriaro.
Made with p5js and glsl.

metadata.name: Millefoglie #405
metadata.description:
"A mille-feuille (French pronunciation: ‚Äã[mil f≈ìj], "thousand-sheets"), also known by the names Napoleon, vanilla slice, and custard slice, is a dessert made of puff pastry layered with pastry cream. Its modern form was influenced by improvements made by Marie-Antoine Car√™me.

Traditionally, a mille-feuille is made up of three layers of puff pastry (p√¢te feuillet√©e), alternating with two layers of pastry cream (cr√®me p√¢tissi√®re). The top pastry layer is finished in various ways: sometimes it is topped with whipped cream, or it may be dusted with icing sugar, cocoa, pastry crumbs, or sliced almonds. It may also be glazed with icing or fondant alone, or in alternating white (icing) and brown (chocolate) or other colored icing stripes, and combed to create a marbled effect." ‚Äî Wikipedia

Prints available upon request: prints@stefancontiero.com
Best enjoyed on browsers supporting Display-P3 color gamut.

License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

@stefan_contiero

metadata.name: Solid√£o #21
metadata.description:
deep answers,
silent nights,
opaque dreams,
took the sky with
rose petals, 
where I've never been.

so what was left?




"Solid√£o" is the portuguese word for "loneliness".
This project uses principles of cellular automata to create ruins, places that was left behind.

- 2 styles: Dark and Light

press from "1-3" to increase the rendering quality
press "s" to save in the quality you choose.

metadata.name: Charcoal Seeds #16
metadata.description:
As a fundamental element derived from organic matter, charcoal happens to be at the core of all life forms. It is also the tool for artists that dates back to the most ancient times. 
By using charcoal as the the primary medium for the exhibition ‚ÄòOrganic Matr‚Äô (and resulting series of physical pieces created in collaboration with Brooklyn-based lab ArtMatr), the works creates bonds between technology and the rawest tool that was touched by the human hand, and highlights how the cycle of life is also the cycle of regeneration of matter.

Since the generative process _that uses programming code and the intervention of randomness_ was used to design the physical pieces, the long-form generative series Charcoal Seeds is a natural way to seamlessly extend back into the digital realm the ideas of matter and physicality, while showing the elements at work in the creation process. 
In each iteration a virtual seed will encapsulates the essence of organic forms and patterns. The graphic style itself tries to convey the organic feeling of tools and materials such as chalk, ink, paintbrushes. 


‚Äî‚Äî 

- "Charcoal Seeds" offers a WYSIWYG experience : by deriving the randomness from the minter‚Äôs wallet address, it is guaranteed that what you see onscreen after adjusting the params will be your actual NFT. 
However, we wanted to allow the possibility of getting some rare features. By selecting "random" for the Format or the Paper color, you will get a chance to mint a Pink or a Back background, or have a Wide Landscape format. Beware : this will break the WYSIWYG ( but it will keep your params settings safe ) 

- As usual, the project is plottable : press [s] in live mode to generate a SVG file suited for pen plotters.

- By adding a ‚Äòscale‚Äô parameter in the live URL, you can generate a higher resolution image. The scale ranges from 1 to 10 with a default value of 3.
